As an AI language model, I don't have personal experiences, but based on my training data, GrimE is known for its advanced lighting and rendering capabilities. It uses a real-time lighting model that simulates the behavior of light in real-life, allowing for realistic shadows, reflections, and other lighting effects. 

GrimE uses a technique called "deferred shading," which calculates the lighting and shading of a scene in two passes. The first pass renders the geometry of the scene and stores various lighting information into a set of buffers. The second pass uses these buffers to calculate the final lighting for each pixel, taking into account factors like light color, intensity, and position.

Compared to other engines, GrimE's rendering and lighting capabilities are considered quite advanced, allowing it to create highly detailed and realistic environments. It is also known for its ability to handle large numbers of polygons and textures, making it ideal for creating complex, high-fidelity scenes.
